At this point, we can safely say that the decision by this legislator to suddenly switch parties will have major consequences for millions of people.

You can read more here: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/05/us/politics/north-carolina-tricia-cotham.html

There are no recall provisions in North Carolina. She will be able to serve her full two-year term, which just began in January. For that period, Republicans will now be in full control.

It is unclear whether she intends to run for re-election or seek another office in 2024.

I have never seen anything like this. 

This legislator was a long-time Democrat and had just been elected on a strongly Democratic platform in a district that votes Democratic by roughly 20 points. 

I am hearing from many of her constituents and they are in a state of shock.

And the state budget - which controls education funding - can now be passed entirely on the basis of Republican votes.

This will likely have a major impact on funding for public education and teacher pay.

I can‚Äôt overstate the consequences of this switch.

While we don‚Äôt know how she will vote on any given bill, dozens of bills that were essentially dead - from elections law changes to reproductive freedom to LGBTQ rights to education policy - may have just sprung back to life.

Until today, Democrats had enough votes to sustain the Governor‚Äôs veto - but only by a margin of one vote in the NC House.

With this switch, Republicans now have a supermajority in both chambers, which just gave them full control for the first time since 2017.

This morning there was a political earthquake in North Carolina.

A legislator in the state House announced she was switching parties from Democrat to Republican.

I want to make sure you understand how dramatic the impact of this one switch will be.

Approximately 4 in 10 Americans with opioid use disorder are covered by Medicaid. The 10 states that have not expanded Medicaid should follow North Carolina‚Äôs example and close the coverage gap so that ALL residents can get the help they need.

https://www.kff.org/medicaid/issue-brief/the-opioid-epidemic-and-medicaids-role-in-facilitating-access-to-treatment/
And we should cancel existing medical debt to ease the burden on those who have already sought help.

Treatment for opioid use disorder is healthcare and healthcare is a human right. We have to pass #MedicareForAll to ensure that everyone who wants to begin recovery doesn‚Äôt have to worry about cost or medical debt.

The bill would have created criminal liability for top executives and penalized drug manufacturers who illegally marketed or distributed opioid products, requiring them to reimburse the country for the harm they caused.

When I visit the communities that have been ravaged by the opioid epidemic, I see victims of greedy pharmaceutical companies that have put profits over patients. To combat these practices, I co-sponsored the Opioid Crisis Accountability and Results Act w/ @BernieSanders in 2019.

üßµ Last week, the FDA approved the over-the-counter Narcan (naloxone), a medication that reverses opioid overdoses. This is a major step. But we must get to the root of the problem: lack of funding for substance use disorder treatment and Big Pharma greed.
